page.title: 02King's Sutton Green
page.content: King's Sutton is one of the largest villages in Northamptonshire and it still has several shops, but you have to go six miles to Banbury to find a market town; in the Domesday Book King's Sutton was recorded as having a market of its own. It was first called Suetone, or Southtown, later it became Sutton Regis because it was part of the Royal estates. From the seventeenth century it was known as King's Sutton. The oldest houses, like the Parish Church, are situated around a small green where the old village stocks are preserved. Most of these buildings are made of the lovely honey-coloured local stone usually called Hornton stone. The Manor is the grandest house in the village.
